title: 105_s1913
content: The Act may be cited as the "Montana Fish and Wildlife Conservation Act of 1998". Congress finds that it is in the interest of the United States for the Secretary of the Interior to sell leaseholds at Canyon Ferry Reservoir in Montana for fair market value. The proceeds will be used to establish a trust for funding to acquire property interests to conserve fish and wildlife, enhance public hunting and fishing opportunities, and increase public access to Federal land in Montana. The sale of leaseholds at Canyon Ferry Reservoir in Montana aims to reduce project debt, enhance public hunting and fishing opportunities, and increase public access to Federal lands in the state. Existing trusts in Montana have already provided significant benefits by conserving wildlife and improving recreational opportunities. The sale of leaseholds at Canyon Ferry Reservoir in Montana will reduce disputes between the Federal Government and leaseholders, increase local tax revenues, and ensure fair value for the property acquisition. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, key definitions include CFRA as Canyon Ferry Recreation Association, Fund as Montana Hunter and Fisherman Access Fund, Lessee as holder of a leasehold, Purchaser as buyer of leaseholds, Reservoir as Canyon Ferry Reservoir, Secretary as Secretary of the Interior, and Trust as Canyon Ferry Trust. The term "Trust" refers to the Canyon Ferry-Missouri River Trust established under section 5(a) of the Act. SEC. 4. SALE OF LEASEHOLDS. The Secretary shall sell all leaseholds at fair market value, including rights, easements for access, and improvements. The leaseholds to be conveyed include 265 cabin sites of the Bureau of. The Secretary will sell 265 cabin sites of the Bureau of Reclamation and any contiguous parcels to eliminate inholdings and facilitate land administration. Acreage and legal descriptions will be agreed upon by the Secretary and the Purchaser. The purchase process will be overseen by the Secretary. The Secretary will sell leaseholds through a purchase process involving sealed bids. A minimum bid will be established based on fair market value, and the leaseholds will be sold to the highest bidder above the minimum bid. The Secretary will sell leaseholds through a sealed bid process with a minimum bid set at fair market value. The highest bidder will have the right of first refusal, and conditions include contributing to the Trust and Fund, as well as paying a percentage to the Treasury. The Secretary will sell leaseholds through a sealed bid process with a minimum bid set at fair market value. The highest bidder will have the right of first refusal and must contribute to the Trust and Fund, as well as pay a percentage to the Treasury. Purchasers are not eligible for a charitable deduction, and leaseholders have the option to purchase at fair market value. Nonpurchasing lessees can continue to lease the property. The Purchaser must compensate lessees for improvements if they decline to purchase the leasehold. Historical use restrictions for leaseholds must be honored. Administrative costs will be incurred. Administrative costs incurred by the Secretary for the conveyance must be reimbursed by the Purchaser. SEC. 5. CANYON FERRY-MISSOURI RIVER TRUST. The Secretary will encourage the establishment of a nonprofit charitable trust called the "Canyon Ferry-Missouri River Trust" to acquire land for conservation and public access along the Missouri River. The trust will have a Board of Trustees representing local agricultural landowners and hunting organizations. The Canyon Ferry-Missouri River Trust will consult with various organizations and governmental bodies in managing the Trust, including hunting organizations, fisheries conservation organizations, land trusts, the Bureau of Reclamation, Forest Service, Bureau of Land Management, Fish and Wildlife Service, Montana Department of Fish, Wildlife, and Parks, Montana Science Institute, and local governmental bodies. The Canyon Ferry-Missouri River Trust's principal amount is inviolate, with earnings used for Trust purposes. Acquired land is managed for Trust objectives. SEC. 6. MONTANA HUNTER AND FISHERMAN ACCESS FUND. Established in the Treasury of the United States is the "Montana Hunter and Fisherman Access Fund" to acquire land in Montana for public access to Federal land for hunting and fishing, and to enhance hunting and fishing opportunities through wildlife conservation. The principal amount of the Fund is protected, while earnings are used for the Fund's purposes. The joint direction of the Chief of the Forest Service, the Director of the Bureau of Land Management, and the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service will manage land acquired for the purposes described in subsection (a).
